headline: Trump latest: Carney says King Charles will go to Canada this month - and confirms he will visit Trump | US News | Sky News
context: We'll be back soon with more US news.

annotations.paragraph: Aside from his big announcements about an upcoming meeting with Donald Trump and King Charles's visit later in the month, Canadian PM Mark Carney also addressed a number of domestic issues in his news conference this afternoon.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the main events related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: He described Canada as a confident nation that practices free speech and respects the law, adding the country "has what everyone wants".
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains general statements about Canada that do not directly relate to the main events.

annotations.paragraph: Here's a summary of those points:
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a transition and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: One comment Donald Trump has been repeating over recent months is that Canada should be the 51st state of the US.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about Trump's views on Canada, which relates to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: He even referred to the country's former prime minister Justin Trudeau as "governor Trudeau".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides additional context on Trump's comments about Canada, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: So, did Trump continue that rhetoric when he held a phone call with Mark Carney?
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a question about Trump's rhetoric, which is relevant to the main premise.

annotations.paragraph: "He did not," Carney said at his news conference earlier.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a direct quote from Carney, contributing to the narrative about Trump's rhetoric.

annotations.paragraph: Carney was also asked whether he had seen signs of respect from the Trump administration towards Canada.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a relevant question about the relationship between Trump and Canada.

annotations.paragraph: "It's always important to distinguish want from reality," he said, adding that Canada becoming a US state will "never ever happen".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides Carney's commentary on the US-Canada relationship, relevant to the article's theme.

annotations.paragraph: Watch Trump speaking in February on why he wants Canada to be America's 51st state:
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a prompt to watch a video, which is not directly informative in the text.

annotations.paragraph: As Mark Carney's news conference wraps up, he's given an insight into what he could be discussing with Donald Trump in Washington next Tuesday.
annotations.reason: Introduces the topic of Carney's upcoming discussion with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: He points to fentanyl tariffs and states they were "not merited to begin with", given Canada's progress on the issue.
annotations.reason: Provides specific details about the topics Carney plans to discuss with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: "There are examples where, certainly from our perspective, the fentanyl tariffs were not merited to begin with, but are even less merited given all the steps that the government of Canada has taken and the progress has been made," he says.
annotations.reason: Offers a direct quote from Carney on the fentanyl tariffs issue.

annotations.paragraph: "But you know, this will be a broader discussion, and it's one of the cards that they have. And therefore we will see how it plays out."
annotations.reason: Provides additional commentary on the nature of the upcoming discussions.

annotations.paragraph: For context: The Trump administration justified its tariffs on Canada by saying they were to stop the spread and manufacturing of the opioid fentanyl, as well as pressuring America's neighbours to limit illegal immigration to the US.
annotations.reason: Gives necessary background on the rationale behind the tariffs.

annotations.paragraph: Carney's predecessor as Canadian prime minister, Justin Trudeau, entered negotiations with Trump earlier this year to try to avoid the tariffs.
annotations.reason: Provides context on previous negotiations related to Trump and Canada.

annotations.paragraph: As part of that, Canada pledged a £1bn border plan - including 10,000 workers, drones, helicopters, a joint taskforce with the US and more - in order to halt the flow of fentanyl and illegal migration.
annotations.reason: Details Canada's response to negotiations with Trump, relevant to the trade and border issues.

annotations.paragraph: But Trump's tariffs have continued.
annotations.reason: Directly relates to the ongoing issue of tariffs between the US and Canada.

annotations.paragraph: He has imposed a 25% tariff on various Canadian goods, along 25% tariffs on steel and aluminium.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about the tariffs imposed by Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Trump did exempt some products under the US-Canada-Mexico trade deal, USMCA.
annotations.reason: Mentions exemptions under a relevant trade deal, adding context to the tariff situation.

annotations.paragraph: Canada has hit back with £32bn worth of tariffs on American goods.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is unrelated to the main topic of King Charles's visit to Canada and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Mark Carney is asked about King Charles's visit to Canada later this month, which he announced in this news conference (see 16.11 post).
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces the topic of King Charles's visit to Canada, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "He will open parliament with the speech from the throne," Carney explains.
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about King Charles's activities during his visit to Canada.

annotations.paragraph: "That clearly underscores the sovereignty of our country."
annotations.reason: This quote provides context on the significance of King Charles's visit to Canada.

annotations.paragraph: Earlier in the news conference, Carney said parliament will be recalled on 26 May before King Charles's speech on 27 May.
annotations.reason: This paragraph gives a timeline of events related to King Charles's visit, which is relevant.

annotations.paragraph: He also said the Queen will join the visit.
annotations.reason: This provides new information about the Queen joining the visit, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Those details have now been confirmed in a statement from Buckingham Palace (see 16.13 post).
annotations.reason: This confirms details about the visit, relevant to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Mark Carney is asked a question on what he hopes to get out of his meeting with Donald Trump next week.
annotations.reason: This introduces a new aspect of the story related to Carney's meeting with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: He says there are "two sets of issues" he wants to discuss.
annotations.reason: This sets up the context for the issues Carney wants to discuss with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: "There are the immediate tariffs... and then there is the broader relationship," he says.
annotations.reason: This provides specific details about the topics Carney plans to discuss with Trump.

annotations.paragraph: "It's important to get engaged immediately, which has always been my intention and has always been his intention."
annotations.reason: The quote is vague and does not provide specific information related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: When asked about how he'll try to avoid an Oval Office row similar to what Volodymyr Zelenskyy experienced, Carney says "I go there with the expectation of difficult but constructive discussions".
annotations.reason: This provides context about Carney's approach to discussions with Trump, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "That's the spirit of the conversations that the president and I had, you go to these meetings well prepared, understanding the objectives of your counterpart and always acting in the best interest of Canada and we'll go from there."
annotations.reason: This offers insight into Carney's diplomatic strategy, relevant to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Watch below: Body language explained during Zelenskyy-Trump Oval Office showdown.
annotations.reason: This is a prompt to watch a video and does not contribute new information to the article.

annotations.paragraph: Turning back to the relationship between Canada and the US, Carney says "our old relationship based on steadily increasing integration is over".
annotations.reason: This statement provides context on the current state of Canada-US relations, relevant to the article.

annotations.paragraph: He says the question is now about how the two nations will cooperate in the future.
annotations.reason: This is a vague generalization about future cooperation without specific details.

annotations.paragraph: Carney says he has had a "very constructive call" with Donald Trump and confirmed that they agreed to meet next Tuesday in Washington - something we told you about in our 15.50 post.
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about a planned meeting between Carney and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: "Our focus will be on both immediate trade pressures and the broader future economic and security relationship between our two sovereign nations," he adds.
annotations.reason: This offers context on the topics to be discussed in the meeting.

annotations.paragraph: "My government will fight to get the best deal for Canada. We will take all the time necessary, but not more, in order to do so."
annotations.reason: This is a general statement about Canada's negotiation stance without new information.

annotations.paragraph: The King and Queen have confirmed their visit to Canada.
annotations.reason: This confirms the visit of the King and Queen to Canada, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Here's a statement from Buckingham Palace that's just been released:
annotations.reason: This is an introductory statement without new information.

annotations.paragraph: The King and Queen will visit Canada from Monday 26th to Tuesday 27th May.
annotations.reason: This provides specific details about the King and Queen's visit to Canada.

annotations.paragraph: The King, accompanied by The Queen, will attend The State Opening of the Parliament of Canada, in Ottawa.
annotations.reason: This gives additional details about the purpose of the visit to Canada.

annotations.paragraph: Carney has started to set out some key events happening in his government over the next few weeks.
annotations.reason: This is a general statement without specific details related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: He says the new cabinet will be sworn in on 12 May, and parliament will be recalled on 26 May.
annotations.reason: This provides specific dates and events related to Carney's government.

annotations.paragraph: Carney also reveals King Charles will be delivering a speech from the throne on 27 May.
annotations.reason: This provides specific information about King Charles' activities related to the visit.

annotations.paragraph: He says the Queen will also join the visit, and describes it as an "historic honour which matches the weight of our times".
annotations.reason: This adds relevant details about the Queen's involvement in the visit.

annotations.paragraph: Mark Carney has taken his seat as his first news conference since his election win gets under way.
annotations.reason: This is background information about Carney's position and does not directly relate to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: It didn't take long for Donald Trump's name to be mentioned...
annotations.reason: This is a vague statement without providing new information.

annotations.paragraph: "On Monday, Canadians elected a new government to stand up to President Trump and to build a strong economy," he says.
annotations.reason: This provides context about the political climate related to Trump.

annotations.paragraph: "Canadians also sent a clear message that their cost of living must come down and their communities need to be safe.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a general statement about Canadian concerns and does not directly relate to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: "As prime minister, I've heard these messages loud and clear, and I will act on them with focus and determination."
annotations.reason: This is a general political statement and does not relate to the headline about King Charles or Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Mark Carney's news conference is starting now in Ottawa.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about a news conference that may relate to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Watch live via the feed at the top of this page.
annotations.reason: This is an instruction for viewing the news conference and does not add information about the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Here's the scene in Ottawa, where we're waiting to hear from Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney, who is about to speak at a news conference.
annotations.reason: This paragraph sets the scene for the news conference, which may relate to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: We're expecting him to set out some details of his plans for government, after his remarkable election win.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is speculative and does not provide concrete information related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Could he also confirm a meeting with Donald Trump?
annotations.reason: This is a speculative question and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney is set to meet Donald Trump in Washington on Tuesday, according to Bloomberg.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about a planned meeting relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: While the official details of the meeting are reportedly still being ironed out, it comes after Trump was full of praise for Carney during his cabinet meeting earlier this week.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the relationship between Trump and Carney, relevant to the meeting.

annotations.paragraph: The US president claimed Carney would visit "within the next week or less" and went on to describe him as a "very nice gentleman".
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a direct quote from Trump, adding relevant context to the meeting.

annotations.paragraph: Watch: Carney says 'Trump is trying to break us' after election win
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a headline for a video and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: Trump revealed that the two leaders shared a phone call on Tuesday, and he said Carney "couldn't have been nicer".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides new information about a phone call between Trump and Carney.

annotations.paragraph: He also joked that both candidates in the Canadian election race - Carney and Conservative Party leader Pierre Poilievre - "hated Trump", but that the conservative Poilievre "hated me more."
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers additional context about Trump's relationship with Canadian political figures.

annotations.paragraph: A reminder, we're expecting to hear from Carney at 4pm UK time in his first news conference since his election win, so it will be interesting to see whether the meeting is mentioned.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about an upcoming event related to Carney.

annotations.paragraph: With Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney speaking later, it's a good time to remind ourselves of his remarkable rise.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a vague generalization and does not provide new information.

annotations.paragraph: From elite banker to a powerful political comeback story, with a smattering of ice hockey along the way, it's quite the biography.
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a vague generalization and does not provide specific information related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Tap below for a full profile of the man many across the world are looking to as someone who could stand up to Trump's US...
annotations.reason: This paragraph is a promotional teaser and does not provide new information related to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: Despite his ongoing row with Harvard (see our previous post), Donald Trump doesn't have beef with every university in the US.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a new fact about Trump's relationship with universities, which is relevant to the broader context of his activities.

annotations.paragraph: Last night, he visited the University of Alabama, and lapped up the adoration of the crowds in deep-red Republican territory.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific information about Trump's recent activities, which is relevant to the article's focus on his current engagements.

annotations.paragraph: He even posted on Truth Social about the experience earlier today...
annotations.reason: This paragraph adds detail about Trump's social media activity related to his visit, contributing to the narrative of his public engagements.

annotations.paragraph:
"Congratulations to the class of 2025. Roll Tide," Trump
told hundreds of Alabama graduates gathered at the
campus's Coleman Coliseum at the start of his commencement speech. "Roll Tide" is a reference to a slogan of support and pride
in the school's football team, known as the Crimson Tide.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about Trump's activities but is not directly related to the headline about King Charles and Trump.

annotations.paragraph:
Trump used the event to celebrate the school and its graduates,
offer some advice and tout his policy successes, such as slowing
illegal immigration and forbidding transgender participation
in collegiate sports.

annotations.paragraph: Here are some pictures from the event...

annotations.paragraph: Meanwhile, Donald Trump is continuing his battle with American universities today.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a new topic unrelated to the headline about King Charles and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Earlier, he posted on Truth Social (where else?) with a new warning for Harvard, one of the most famous universities in the US.
annotations.reason: This paragraph discusses Trump's social media activity unrelated to the headline about King Charles and Trump.

annotations.paragraph: Trump's administration has been locked in a battle with the Ivy League institution, based in Cambridge, Massachusetts.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about Trump's administration's conflict with Harvard, which is relevant to the broader narrative of Trump's actions.

annotations.paragraph: Trump's team has accused Harvard of ideological bias and allowing antisemitism during campus protests last year against Israel's war in Gaza.
annotations.reason: This paragraph adds specific accusations made by Trump's team against Harvard, contributing to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: His administration began a review of $9bn (£6.7bn) in federal grants for Harvard in March, and demanded the university screens international students for those "hostile to American values" and the end of all diversity, equality and inclusion programmes.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides details on actions taken by Trump's administration against Harvard, which is relevant to the story.

annotations.paragraph: The university's president Alan Garber has remained defiant and rejected those and other reforms, and Harvard is suing Trump's government.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes Harvard's response to Trump's actions, which is relevant to the ongoing conflict.

annotations.paragraph: Now, the president says he'll strip Harvard of its tax exempt status - something he's already threatened to do before.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides an update on Trump's threats against Harvard, contributing to the narrative.

annotations.paragraph: Here's what he said earlier today...
annotations.reason: The paragraph is a vague introduction without specific information.

annotations.paragraph: Donald Trump was asked about Mark Carney during his cabinet meeting at the White House this week.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context about the setting where Trump discussed Carney.

annotations.paragraph: Trump claimed Carney will come to the White House "within the next week or less".
annotations.reason: This paragraph contains a direct claim about Carney's visit to the White House.

annotations.paragraph: The US president also called Carney a "very nice gentleman" who, during their phone call on Tuesday, "couldn’t have been nicer".
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides a quote from Trump about his interaction with Carney.

annotations.paragraph: The president joked that both candidates in the Canadian election race - Carney and Conservative Party leader Pierre Poilievre - "hated Trump", but that the conservative Poilievre "hated me more."
annotations.reason: This paragraph includes a quote from Trump that adds context to his views on Canadian politics.

annotations.paragraph: Such is Donald Trump's influence in 2025 that he's being given credit for swaying elections in other countries.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Trump's influence in international politics, which is relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: On Monday, Canada's Liberal Prime Minister Mark Carney completed a staggering turnaround for his party's political fortunes.
annotations.reason: This paragraph introduces a key event related to the political context mentioned in the headline.

annotations.paragraph: His win in the Canadian election was largely based on his tough stance on Trump's tariffs, which have threatened Canada's economy.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides specific details about the election win and its connection to Trump, relevant to the headline.

annotations.paragraph: The background
annotations.reason: This is a section header and does not provide any new information.

annotations.paragraph: With his slogan "Canada Strong", Carney saw off his main rival, Conservative Pierre Poilievre, who ended up losing his own seat in one of the biggest shocks of the contest.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides additional context on the election outcome, relevant to the main story.

annotations.paragraph: Just a few months ago, Poilievre's party had a big lead in the polls. But Trump's tariffs unleashed a Canadian patriotism, and Poilievre struggled to adapt after previously trying to imitate Trump in some ways.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on Canadian political dynamics influenced by Trump, which is relevant to the article's focus on Trump-related news.

annotations.paragraph: The unpopular Liberal Justin Trudeau, who had been prime minister for ten years, quit in January - paving the way for Carney, who won a contest in his party, and then with the country.
annotations.reason: This paragraph offers background on Carney's rise to power, which is relevant to understanding his current role and actions.

annotations.paragraph: Carney has never been a politician before. He's best known here for being the Bank of England governor during Brexit and other crises.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant background on Carney's professional history, which is pertinent to his current political role.

annotations.paragraph: He used that reputation for dealing with tricky times in the election.
annotations.reason: This paragraph adds context to Carney's political strategy, which is relevant to his current position and actions.

annotations.paragraph: What's happening today?
annotations.reason: This is a vague prompt without any substantive information.

annotations.paragraph: Carney will give a news conference in Ottawa at 4pm UK time today, his office said in a statement on Thursday.
annotations.reason: Provides specific information about Carney's upcoming news conference.

annotations.paragraph: It will be his first time addressing the media since his election win.
annotations.reason: Offers context about the significance of the news conference.

annotations.paragraph: Earlier this week, Trump suggested the pair had a good phone call, and that Carney would visit the White House soon.
annotations.reason: Relates directly to the headline about Carney's potential visit to Trump.

annotations.paragraph: It will be interesting to see if Carney does visit Trump, given his tough talk about making Canada self sufficient, and pivoting the country towards other allies like the UK and Europe.
annotations.reason: Speculates on the implications of Carney's visit, adding context to the main story.
